questions.text: A 32-year-old male presents with intense itching and a rash on his lower legs and arms after camping near a river. Examination reveals multiple papules and thickened, scaly skin. He reports blurred vision and seeing "floaters," with an ophthalmological exam showing keratitis and punctate keratopathy. Which vector should you be particularly vigilant for to prevent further transmission of this infection?

A microbiologist is studying various tissue nematodes and comes across a specimen characterized by continuous line of nucleus as shown in the image. Which of the following nematodes is most likely to be identified from this specimen?

questions.text: A 35-year-old patient presents with intermittent fever, lymphadenopathy, and swelling in the right leg. Blood tests show eosinophilia, and the patient has a history of travel to endemic regions. Which of the following statements about the laboratory tests for diagnosing filariasis is incorrect?

options.label: A
options.text: Nucleopore filtration is used to concentrate microfilaria in blood samples.

options.label: B
options.text: USG scrotum can identify motile adult worms within dilated lymphatics

options.label: C
options.text: Immunochromatographic test (ICT) detects W. bancrofti antigen in serum

options.label: D
options.text: Antibody demonstration distinguishes between current and past infections

questions.correct_answer: D. Antibody demonstration distinguishes between current and past infections

questions.text: Which of the following statements regarding classical and occult filariasis is incorrect?

options.label: A
options.text: Microfilaria is present in the blood in both classical and occult filariasis

options.label: B
options.text: Classical filariasis is due to adult worms; occult filariasis is from hypersensitivity

options.label: C
options.text: Classical filariasis doesn't respond to treatment; occult filariasis responds to DEC

options.label: D
options.text: Classical filariasis has lymphangitis; occult filariasis shows eosinophilic granulomas

questions.correct_answer: A. Microfilaria is present in the blood in both classical and occult filariasis

Occult filariasis

developing worms

Eosinophilic granuloma formation

Present in blood

Present in tissues but not in blood

Serological Tests

Complement fixation test not so sensitive

Complement fixation test highly sensitive

Therapeutic Response (Option C)

No response

Prompt response to

diethylcarbamazine (DEC)

questions.text: A healthcare team in an endemic region is educating the community on ways to prevent Dracunculus medinensis infection. Which of the following would be the best advice to reduce the risk of infection?

options.label: A
options.text: Use bed nets to avoid mosquito bites

options.label: B
options.text: Avoid consuming raw vegetables and fruits

options.label: C
options.text: Boil or filter drinking water to eliminate Cyclops

questions.correct_answer: C. Boil or filter drinking water to eliminate Cyclops
questions.explanation:
Dracunculus Medinensis

Life Cycle
  • Definitive host: Human
  • Intermediate host: Cyclops
  • Transmission: Ingestion of water-containing Cyclops with L3 larvae.
  • In Humans: L3 larvae released in the stomach, penetrate the intestine, migrate to thoracic muscles, become adult worms, and emerge through the skin as blisters.
  • In Cyclops: L1 larvae develop into L3 larvae, becoming infective over two weeks.

 

Pathogenesis & Symptoms

Symptoms appear ~1 year after infection when the female worm emerges.

  • Symptoms: painful blisters with erythema, fever, nausea, pruritus; common sites include lower leg, ankle, foot.
  • Secondary bacterial infections possible at blister sites.

Laboratory Diagnosis
  • Detection of Adult Worm: Identify female worms in blisters; X-ray for calcified worms.
  • Detection of L1 Larvae: Microscopic examination after placing the leg in cold water.
  • Antibody Detection: ELISA for antibodies against D. medinensis.
  • Eosinophilia: Peripheral blood eosinophilia may be present.

Treatment

Worm Removal: Gentle extraction over 15-20 days with a stick; avoid heavy pressure.

Symptomatic Treatment: Wet compresses, analgesics, topical antibiotics; no known effective anti-helminthic drugs. (Option D)

Eradication Efforts in India

Initiatives: Launched in 1984 with WHO assistance, focused on:

  • Safe drinking water provision (filtration, hand pumps)
  • Controlling Cyclops populations by using larvicides (e.g., abate).
  • Educating the public on boiling or filtering drinking water. (Option C)
  • Treating identified cases to prevent further transmission.

questions.text: A 29-year-old female presents with symptoms including fever, myalgia, and periorbital swelling. She mentions consuming undercooked pork during a recent camping trip. On physical examination, she exhibits noticeable edema around the eyes, tenderness in the muscles, and a palpable rash. Which diagnostic test is the most definitive for confirming the suspected condition?

options.label: B
options.text: Stool examination for ova and parasites

questions.text: A 30-year-old man presents with complaints of muscle pain, fever, and swelling. He reports recently consuming pork meat during a camping trip. On examination, he has a finding as shown in the image & muscle tenderness. Laboratory investigations reveal elevated eosinophil counts and creatine kinase (CK) levels. What is the most likely diagnosis?

A 30-year-old man who recently traveled to a tropical region presents with nausea, intermittent epigastric pain, occasional loose stools, and a maculopapular rash on his perineum. Stool culture identifies Strongyloides stercoralis rhabditiform larvae. Which treatment should be administered?
questions.explanation:
Pathogenesis and Clinical Features of Strongyloides Stercoralis Infection
 

Effect of Migrating Larvae
  • Asymptomatic Infection: Over 50% may be asymptomatic.
  • Rashes: Recurrent maculopapular or urticarial rashes on buttocks, perineum, and thighs.
  • Cutaneous Larva Migrans: Serpiginous rash (larva currens) advancing up to 10 cm/hour.
  • Pulmonary Symptoms: Rare, mainly in chronic obstructive lung disease.

Effects of Adult Worms & Filariform Larvae
  • Mild to Moderate Load: Epigastric pain, nausea, diarrhea, constipation, and blood loss.
  • Heavy Larval Load: Risk of hyperinfection syndrome and disseminated strongyloidiasis.

Hyperinfection Syndrome
  • Cause: Repeated autoinfection leads to increased filariform larvae.
  • Risk Factors: Glucocorticoid therapy, immunosuppressive conditions, HTLV-1/HIV coinfection.
  • Features: Colitis, enteritis, malabsorption, possible progression to disseminated strongyloidiasis.

Disseminated Strongyloidiasis
  • Pathophysiology: Larvae invade GIT and other organs. Disrupted mucosa may allow enteric flora to cause bacterial sepsis, pneumonia, or meningitis.
  • Clinical Manifestations: CNS invasion, brain abscesses, meningitis; larvae in CSF. Eosinophilia, often absent in severe cases.
  • Mortality Rate: Nearing 100% untreated; over 25% even with treatment.




 

Laboratory Diagnosis

Stool Microscopy: Rhabditiform larvae; requires multiple samples (4+) for accurate diagnosis.

Microscopy of Other Specimens: Entero-test for duodenal aspirates; high filariform larvae are found in stool, sputum, and tissue biopsies for disseminated cases.

Stool Culture: Differentiates rhabditiform from hookworm larvae.

Serology: ELISA for antibodies; may show cross-reactivity, less effective for recent infections.

Coproantigen Detection: Antigen capture ELISA specific to Strongyloides.

Molecular Diagnosis: Real-time PCR targeting specific genes.
 

Treatment
  • Asymptomatic Treatment: Strongyloidiasis should be treated regardless of symptoms due to the risk of hyperinfection.
  • Ivermectin (200 mg/kg daily for 2 days) (Option C)

Parasitic infection via skin penetration

Protozoan infections

Nematode infections
  • Cutaneous leishmaniasis
  • Cutaneous amoebiasis
  • Acanthamoeba skin lesions
  • Trypanosoma chancre and chagoma
  • Sarcocystosis
  • Cutaneous filariasis
  • Dracunculiasis
  • Trichinellosis
  • Cutaneous larva migrans

Cestode infections

Trematode infections
  • Muscular cysticercosis
  • Sparganosis (Spirometra)
  • Cercarial dermatitis
  • Cutaneous paragonimiasis

questions.text: A 30-year-old woman presents with intermittent abdominal pain, diarrhea, and weight loss over the past month. She has a history of walking barefoot in a rural tropical region. A stool sample reveals the following findings. Which larval stage of the parasite is most likely identified in the stool sample?
questions.explanation:
Rhabditiform larva (Option A)

Filariform larva (Option B)

3d stage of the larva (L3).

Formed when eggs hatch in the small intestine.

Developed from two molts of the L1 larva.

Measures approximately 0.25 mm in length with a short muscular double-bulb esophagus.

Measures about 0.55 mm in length, characterized by a long, slender shape, uniform esophagus & notched tail.

Found in feces.

Seen in hyperinfection & disseminated infection, may show in sputum, stool and body fluids.

Diagnostic form

Infective form

Nematode

Infective form

Route

Ascaris (Roundworm)

Embryonated eggs

Fecal-oral

Enterobius (Pinworm)

Embryonated eggs

Fecal-oral

Trichuris trichiura

Embryonated eggs

Fecal-oral

Ancylostoma (Hookworm)

Filariform larva

Skin

Strongyloides Stercoralis

Filariform larva

Skin

Trichinella spiralis

Encysted larva

Carnivorism

Dracunculus medinensis

L3 larva

Ingestion of infected Cyclops

questions.text: A 40-year-old man from a rural village in South India presents with a chronic cough, intermittent wheezing, and vague abdominal pain. His symptoms have been present for several months, and a recent stool examination reveals rhabditiform larvae. Which of the following is the most likely route of infection in this patient?

options.label: A
options.text: Ingestion of food contaminated with an embryonated egg

options.label: C
options.text: Ingestion of food contaminated with rhabditiform larvae

options.label: D
options.text: Skin penetration by rhabditiform larvae from contaminated soil

questions.correct_answer: B. Skin penetration by filariform larvae
questions.explanation:
Strongyloides Stercoralis (Threadworm)
 

Morphology

Smallest nematode known to cause human infection.

Forms: Exists in three forms: adult worms, larvae (4 stages), & eggs.

Adult Worm:

  • Only females inhabit the human small intestine (2–3 mm long).
  • Males are free-living in the environment.

Eggs: Ovoviviparous, hatch into larvae immediately upon laying. (Option A)

Life Cycle

Hosts: Primarily humans; occasionally domestic pets act as reservoirs.

Infective Form: L3 (filariform) larva.

Transmission:

  • Skin penetration by L3 larva (e.g., walking barefoot). (Option B)
  • Autoinfection, where larvae mature within the host, sustaining infection for decades.

 
 

Phases of Infection

Migratory Phase: L3 larvae enter subcutaneous venules, reach lungs via venous circulation, migrate to alveolar spaces, ascend to the pharynx, and are swallowed to enter the GIT.

Intestinal Phase: L3 larvae mature into adult females in the small intestine mucosa (males are absent in humans).

Female worms lay eggs through parthenogenesis, & rhabditiform (L1) (Option C & D) larvae hatch & are either excreted in feces or mature to L3 for autoinfection.

Autoinfection & Chronicity
  • L1 larvae in the intestine can transform into L3 larvae within the host, penetrate the intestinal wall or perianal skin, enter circulation, and migrate to the lungs.
  • This can sustain infection for up to 30–40 years and may lead to disseminated disease.
 

Environmental Development

Direct Development: L1 larvae molt to L3 in moist, warm soil, becoming directly infective to humans (common in temperate climates).

Indirect Development: L1 larvae molt into adults (both sexes) in tropical climates. These adults reproduce, producing eggs that hatch into L1 larvae, which then develop into infective L3 larvae.

questions.text: A male patient comes with complaints of rashes on the skin that appear as follows. He gives a history of walking barefoot in soil in the fields near his house. Which organism could be the most probable cause of this condition?
questions.explanation:
Cutaneous larva migrans
  • It is also known as the creeping eruption (also known as ground itch).
  • This condition is caused by an infection by a nematode larvae through skin penetration.

Etiology

Common causes:

  • Nonhuman hookworm species:
    • Ancylostoma braziliense
    • A. caninum

Pathogenesis

Lifecycle:

  • Parasite eggs are excreted in the feces of infected animals and hatch in soil.
  • Infection occurs when contaminated soil comes into contact with human skin.
  • Larvae penetrate the skin, causing infection, and migrate beneath the epidermis.

In human hosts:

  • Humans are accidental hosts; hence, the larvae cannot penetrate the deeper layers of the skin (basement membrane).
  • So, the disease remains confined to the outer skin layers.

Clinical features

Creeping eruptions:

  • Itchy papules develop into serpiginous tunnels in the epidermis.
  • The lesions shift with larval movements, leading to the name "creeping eruption."
  • Secondary bacterial infections may arise from scratching.

Transient creeping eruptions:

  • Occasionally caused by the human hookworm, Necator americanus.
  • Other conditions like gnathostomiasis and sparganosis may produce similar symptoms.
  • The lesions are deeper and subcutaneous or in the muscles.
  • Loeffler’s syndrome may develop in many cases.

Clinical diagnosis
  • Eosinophilia is rare and occurs primarily with Loeffler's syndrome.
  • Serological tests are not developed.
  • Larvae are rarely found on biopsy; hence, diagnosis relies on clinical features.

Treatment
  • Medications:
    • Thiabendazole is effective for treatment.
  • Lesion management:
    • Freezing the advancing part of the eruption with ethyl chloride is effective for localized lesions.

 

Cutaneous larva migrans

Visceral larva migrans

Definition

  • This is a serpiginous skin eruption due to burrowing larvae of animal hookworms.
  • It is caused by non-human nematodes that are unable to develop in human hosts and instead migrate through tissues as larvae.
  • The migration of the larvae through the skin causes an eosinophilic inflammation.

Tissue involved

It involves the skin

Involves various organs of the body like the liver, lungs, and eyes.

Infecting organisms

Mostly by non-human hookworms like

  • A.caninum
  • A.braziliense
  • Uncinaria stenocephala
  • Bunostomum phlebotomum

Mainly by dog and cat roundworms like

  • Toxocara canis (Option D)
  • Toxocara cati
  • Ascaris suum (Option B)
  • Angiostrongylus cantonensis
  • Gnathostoma spinigerum (Option A)
  • Anisakis simplex
  • Baylisascaris procyonis

Portal of entry

Penetration of the skin by larva

Ingestion of infected eggs

Eosinophilia

Mild

Persistent high

Serodiagnosis

Not developed

Well developed

Treatment

Thiabendazole

Diethylcarbamazine and prednisolone

questions.text: Identify the distinguishing features of Old World hookworms from New World hookworms.

options.label: A
options.text: The presence of four ventral teeth and two dorsal knob-like teeth in the adult worm

options.label: B
options.text: A lesser incidence of pulmonary reactions associated with Old World hookworms

options.label: C
options.text: The presence of two ventral and two dorsal chitinous cutting plates in the adult worm

options.label: D
options.text: The head of the larva bends in the opposite direction to the curvature of the body

questions.correct_answer: A. The presence of four ventral teeth and two dorsal knob-like teeth in the adult worm
questions.explanation:
Features

Ancylostoma duodenale

(Old World)

Necator americanus

(New World)

Eggs

Similar

Similar

Larva (1st & 2nd stage)

Similar

Similar

Adult worms

Size

Larger and thicker

Small and slender

Buccal capsule

4 ventral teeth and 2 dorsal knob-like teeth

2 ventral and 2 dorsal chitinous cutting plates (Option C)

Pathogenicity

More

Comparatively less

Caudal spine in female

Present

Absent

Filariform worms

The anterior end bends in the same direction as the curvature of the body (vs Option D)

The anterior end is bent in the opposite direction to the curvature of the body

Pulmonary reaction

More common (vs Option B)

Less common

Life span

2-7 years

4-20 years

Filariform larvae images

Adult worms

questions.text: A group of doctors conduct a health checkup camp in a village. A screening for hookworm infection in the community is done. The Chandler’s index of the community is 400 eggs/gram. What does this observation signify?
questions.correct_answer: D. Indicates major public health problem
questions.explanation:
Average no. of eggs per gm of stool

Public health importance of hookworm infection

<200

Not of much importance (Option C)

200-250

Indicates potential damage (Option A)

250-300

Indicates minor public health problem (Option B)

>300

Major public health issue

Clinical features

Affect due to migrating larvae

Affect due to adult worms in the intestine
  • Cutaneous lesions:
    • Pruritic maculopapular dermatitis and rashes (referred to as "ground itch") at the site of skin penetration.
    • Serpiginous tracks may form due to subcutaneous larval migration.
  • Respiratory symptoms:
    • Mild transient pneumonitis may occur due to migrating larvae in the lungs, leading to asthma and bronchitis, but less frequently than in ascariasis.
  • Asymptomatic infections:
    • Most hookworm infections show no symptoms.
  • Early intestinal phase:
    • Infections with a lower worm load can lead to epigastric pain, inflammatory diarrhea, and eosinophilia.
  • Late intestinal phase:
    • Heavy worm loads result in iron deficiency anemia and protein-energy malnutrition, with symptoms like weakness, shortness of breath, and, rarely, cognitive impairments.
  • Wakana disease:
    • Caused by ingestion of L3 larvae of A.duodenale, leading to both gastrointestinal and pulmonary symptoms, such as nausea, vomiting, pharyngeal irritation, cough, dyspnea, and hoarseness.

questions.text: A patient comes with mild epigastric pain, weakness, and diarrhea. On further evaluation, he is found to have anemia and eosinophilia. Stool examination reveals eggs of Ancylostoma. Which of the following differentiates a male hookworm from a female?

options.label: D
options.text: Genital opening at the junction of the middle and posterior 3rd of the body

questions.explanation:
Ancylostoma duodenale / Hookworm

These are mostly found in the jejunum of infected humans > duodenum > ileum.

Morphology

  • The adult worms are stout and cylindrical.
  • The body is curved (concave dorsally and convex ventrally).
  • The anterior end is constricted and bent dorsally, following the general curvature of the body, which is why they are called hookworms.
  • A prominent buccal capsule, reinforced with a hard chitin-like substance, features six teeth:
    • Four hook-like teeth ventrally
    • Two knob-like teeth with a median cleft dorsally

Female adult worm

Male adult worm

Larger in size

Smaller in size (vs Option C)

Copulatory bursa is absent

The copulatory bursa is present

Genital opening is at the junction of the middle and posterior 3rd of the body

The genital opening is at the cloaca along with the anus (vs Option D)

The posterior end is tapering

The posterior end is expanded like an umbrella (vs Option B)

Eggs

  • Shape: The egg is oval or elliptical.
  • Color: Colorless and not bile-stained.
  • Shell: Surrounded by a thin, transparent hyaline shell membrane.
  • Floats in saturated salt solution.
  • Development:
    • Initially, the egg contains an unsegmented ovum when released into the intestine.
    • As it travels down the intestine, the ovum develops.
    • When passed in feces, it contains a segmented ovum, typically with four or eight blastomeres.
    • There is a clear space between the segmented ovum and the eggshell.



 

Epidemiology

Prevalence in India:

  • N. americanus is predominant in South India, while A. duodenale is more common in North India.

Age and sex distribution:

  • Males and young adults are more commonly affected.
  • Anemia due to iron loss is particularly severe in children and pregnant women.

Endemic index:

  • Chandler’s index is utilized in epidemiological studies to estimate the morbidity and mortality associated with hookworm infection, which is influenced by the worm load in the community.

Lifecycle:

  • Ancylostoma has only one host, which is man.
  • The infective form is the third-stage (L3) filariform larva.
  • Mode of transmission:
    • Via the skin penetration by the larva while walking in dampened soil barefoot.
  • There are three phases of development:
    • Migratory phase: Movement of larva from point of penetration to lungs (alveolar space) to pharynx in sputum to the intestine.
    • Intestinal phase: The L3 larva molts in the small intestine and attaches to the intestinal mucosa. Fertilization and laying of eggs occur in the intestine.
    • Development in soil: Immature eggs become mature in the soil and become embryonated. The L1 (rhabditiform) larva hatches and molts twice into the L3 larva which is the infectious form.

questions.text: An 8-year-old child is brought by her parents with complaints of passing urine in bed at night for a month. She also complains of itching around her perianal region. On examination, she has perianal pruritis. The NIH swab method is done. Which of the following is false about this method and its findings?

options.label: A
options.text: The sample is collected from the perianal region in this method for microscopy

options.label: B
options.text: The eggs are observed to have a planoconvex shape

options.label: D
options.text: A piece of cellophane tape is applied to the perianal region to collect the sample

questions.correct_answer: D. A piece of cellophane tape is applied to the perianal region to collect the sample
questions.explanation:
Microscopy

Microscopic examination of perianal skin samples is the preferred method for detecting characteristic pinworm eggs.
 

Specimen collection methods
  • The perianal samples are collected early in the morning before going to the toilet or bathing, as the female worm migrates to lay eggs in the perianal region at night.
  • Scotch tape method:
    • Apply a piece of cellophane tape to the perianal region.
    • Mount the tape on a clear glass slide with a drop of saline for microscopic examination.
  • NIH swab method:
    • Use the NIH swab, which consists of a glass rod with cellophane tape attached by a rubber band.
    • Roll the cellophane part over the perineal and perianal skin to collect the sample. (Option A)
  • Dirt from under fingernails can sometimes show eggs in infected children.
 

Observation


 
  • The eggs are planoconvex, with one side convex and the other side flat, measuring approximately 50–60 µm in length. (Option B)
  • Freshly passed eggs are embryonated and contain a tadpole-shaped larva inside (become infectious after 6 hours). (Option C)
  • Color and Staining:
    • The eggs are colorless and do not exhibit bile staining when observed in a saline mount.
  • Floatation:
    • These eggs are capable of floating in a saturated salt solution.

Biopsy of appendix

 
  • The eggs of E.vermiocularis are seen.
  • There is extensive lymphoid hyperplasia of the mucosa.

questions.text: A 5-year-old child is brought to the hospital by her parents complaining of her waking up during the night with intense itching in the perianal region. The parents also noticed worms in the child’s perianal region, especially during the night. Which of the following stages of this organism is infectious to humans?
questions.explanation:
Epidemiology:

  • The most common age group are school children.
  • Infections can persist for years due to auto-infective cycles.
  • Factors contributing to infection include:
    • Overcrowding
    • Impaired hygiene
    • Poor personal care practices (such as nail-biting and inadequate handwashing).

Morphology

Adult worm
  • The adults are short, white, and fusiform, resembling bits of white thread.
  • The mouth is surrounded by three wing-like structures called cervical alae, which are transversely striated.

Female worm

(Option C)
  • Females are long.
  • The posterior third tapers into a thin, pointed, pin-like tail.
  • Females are oviparous.

Male worm

(Option D)
  • The posterior end is tightly curved ventrally, sharply truncated, and has a prominent copulatory spicule.

Eggs

  • The eggs are colorless and not bile-stained
  • They float in saturated salt solution and have an elongated ovoid shape.
  • Each egg contains a tadpole-shaped, coiled embryo that becomes infectious only 6 hours after being deposited.

questions.text: A patient presents with abdominal pain and anorexia. She also complains of bloody diarrhea and generalized weakness. During stool examination, the following was observed: Which of the following drugs is the best choice for treatment?

A 6-year-old child is brought with abdominal pain. On further evaluation, he is anemic and has growth retardation, and the physician suspects trichuriasis. Which of the following is true regarding the lifecycle of the organism? The eggs hatch into the larvae in the small intestine Man is the intermediate host in its lifecycle The larva is the infective form The development of the egg takes place in the soil
questions.explanation:
Morphology



 

Adult worm
  • The male worm is 30-45 mm long.
  • The female worm is 40-50 mm long (slightly larger).
  • Appearance:
    • Flesh-colored.
    • Whip-shaped: anterior (3/5) thin and thread-like; posterior (2/5) thick and fleshy (like a handle).
    • The end of the male worms is coiled ventrally.
    • The end of the female worm is straight, blunt, and rounded.
  • Body structure:
    • The anterior portion contains a capillary esophagus.
    • The posterior part contains the intestines and reproductive organs.
  • Lifespan: 5-10 years.

Eggs

 


 

Characteristics:

  • The eggs appear brown as they are bile-stained.
  • They are barrel-shaped.
  • They have a triple shell with a brown outer layer and a colorless mucus plug at each pole containing an unsegmented ovum.

Infectivity:

  • Freshly passed eggs contain an unsegmented ovum and are not infective for humans.
  • The egg floats in a saturated salt solution.
  • The fertilized female lays about 5,000 eggs per day.




 

Epidemiology
  • Distribution:
    • Worldwide, it has a higher prevalence in tropical regions.
    • Common in tropical Africa, South America, and Southeast Asia.
    • Widespread in India.
  • Prevalence:
    • An estimated 800 million people are infected globally.
    • While whipworm infections are frequent, whipworm disease is relatively rare.

questions.text: A 5-year-old boy is brought to the clinic with a 2-week history of fever, cough, and abdominal pain. His mother mentions that he often plays in a garden where their dog defecates. A blood test reveals eosinophilia and elevated liver enzymes. A chest X-ray shows bilateral pulmonary infiltrates. Which of the following is the most likely cause of his symptoms?
questions.explanation:
Visceral larva migrans

Visceral Larva Migrans is caused by the migration of larvae from nonhuman nematodes that infect humans via the oral route.
 

Etiology

Most commonly caused by Toxocara canis (Option C) (dog ascarid) and less frequently by Toxocara cati (Option A) (cat ascarid).

Other potential causes include:

  • Anisakis (marine animal ascarids) (Option B)
  • Gnathostoma spinigerum
  • Angiostrongylus cantonensis
 

Pathogenesis
  • Infective eggs in the soil contaminated by dog & cat feces are ingested.
  • Larvae hatch in the small intestine, penetrate the gut wall, and migrate to the liver.
  • They may remain in the liver or move to other organs (lungs, brain, eyes) without developing into adults, causing granulomatous lesions & local tissue damage.

 

Clinical Features

More common in children due to soil ingestion.

Common findings include:

  • Fever
  • Hepatomegaly
  • Pneumonitis
  • Hyperglobulinemia
  • Pica
  • Possible neurological disturbances (neural larva migrans)
  • Endophthalmitis (ophthalmic larva migrans)
  • Marked leukocytosis
  • Persistently high eosinophilia
 

Diagnosis

Diagnosed through serological tests such as:

  • Passive hemagglutination
  • Bentonites flocculation
  • Microprecipitation
  • Enzyme-linked immunosorbent assay (ELISA) is more specific for diagnosing toxocariasis.
 

Treatment

Diethylcarbamazine (DEC): 100 mg TDS for 3 weeks in adults to kill larvae and halt the disease.

Prednisolone: Should be administered concurrently.

Prophylaxis

Deworming of household pets is essential for preventing soil contamination and reducing transmission risk.

questions.text: A 35-year-old woman presents with abdominal pain, diarrhea, and recent weight loss after consuming unwashed vegetables in a rural area. Upon examination, a diagnostic test reveals the presence of eggs in her stool. Which of the following best describes the egg shown below?

options.label: A
options.text: It floats in saturated salt solution

options.label: B
options.text: It does not float in saturated salt solution

options.label: C
options.text: It has translucent shell with three layers

options.label: D
options.text: It has a large unsegmented ovum with coarse lecithin granules

questions.correct_answer: B. It does not float in saturated salt solution
questions.explanation:
Laboratory diagnosis & Treatment of Ascaris lumbricoides

Stool Examination
  • Detects both fertilized & unfertilized eggs using saline and iodine wet mount.
  • If negative, concentration by sedimentation is recommended (floatation is ineffective as unfertilized eggs do not float).

Adult Worm Detection
  • Occasionally visible in stool or sputum. Barium X-ray may show worms in the intestine as "trolley car lines" if aligned in parallel.
  • Ultrasound or cholangiopancreatography helps detect worms in extraintestinal sites.

Larva Detection
  • During early pulmonary migration, larvae may appear in sputum or gastric aspirates before stool detection.

Serology
  • Antibody testing (e.g., ELISA) is sensitive but cannot distinguish recent from past infections and may cross-react with other helminths.

Molecular Methods
  • PCR can identify Ascaris in stool, and differentiate between Ascaris, Trichuris, and hookworm.
  • Real-time PCR quantifies parasite load.

Other Indicators
  • Eosinophilia is common in early lung stages.
  • Charcot-Leyden crystals may appear in sputum and stool.

Treatment
  • Albendazole: 400 mg as a single dose.
  • Mebendazole: 100 mg twice daily for 3 days or 500 mg as a single dose.

Unfertilized Egg

Fertilized Egg
  • It is Elliptical, narrow, & long
  • Size: 80 µm x 55 µm
  • Shell: Thin with an irregular albumin coating
  • Contents: Small, atrophied ovum with disorganized refractile granules
  • Does not Float in saturated salt solution. (Option B)
  • Round or oval in shape.
  • Size: 60-75 µm x 40-45 µm
  • Color: Golden brown, bile-stained
  • Shell: Thick, smooth, translucent with three layers
    • Outer: Coarsely mammillated albuminous coat
    • Middle: Thick transparent layer
    • Inner: Lipoidal vitelline membrane (Option C)
  • Decorticated Variant: Some eggs lack the outer mammillated coat.
  • Contents: Large unsegmented ovum with coarse lecithin granules, leaving clear areas at poles (Option D)
  • Floats in saturated salt solution. (Option A)

FERTILISED

UNFERTILISED

DECORTICATED

questions.text: A 7-year-old boy presents with a 2-week history of cough, chest discomfort, and fever. His parents report that he has been playing in a community garden and often eats unwashed vegetables. Laboratory tests reveal eosinophilia and pulmonary infiltrates. What is the most likely diagnosis for this child?
questions.explanation:
Life Cycle of Ascaris
  • Host: Humans only.
  • Infective Form: Embryonated eggs with L2 larvae.
  • Transmission: Ingestion of eggs from contaminated soil, food, or water. (Option C)

Life Cycle Phases

Migratory Phase
  • L2 larvae hatch, molt to L3, penetrate the intestine and travel to the lungs via the heart.
  • In the lungs, they molt to L4, migrate to the pharynx, and are swallowed back into the intestine.

Intestinal Phase
  • L4 larvae become adult worms in the small intestine.
  • Females lay fertilized eggs in feces; unfertilized eggs may also be laid.

Development in Soil
  • Fertilized eggs become infective embryonated (L2 larvae) in 2 weeks under suitable conditions.
  • Unfertilized eggs disintegrate and are non-infective.
  • Embryonated eggs can survive for up to 15 years due to a thick eggshell and ascaroside, a resistant lipoprotein.

Pathogenesis and Clinical Features
  • Caused by the host immune response, larval migration, adult worm obstruction, and nutritional deficiencies.
  • Incubation: 60–70 days.
 

Pulmonary Phase
  • Symptoms appear within two weeks post-ingestion: cough, chest discomfort, and fever.
  • Severe cases may lead to Loeffler’s syndrome, characterized by eosinophilic pneumonia and transient lung infiltrates.
 

Intestinal Phase
  • Most infections are asymptomatic, but malnutrition and growth retardation can occur, particularly in children <5 years.
  • Complications include intestinal obstruction, perforation, intussusception, or volvulus in older children.

Extraintestinal Complications

Larger worms may obstruct the biliary tree, causing biliary colic or pancreatitis.

Allergic Reactions

Reactions such as fever, urticaria, angioedema, and conjunctivitis may arise due to toxins released by adult worms.

questions.text: A 7-year-old child presents with abdominal discomfort, growth retardation, and a cough. The clinician suspects a parasitic infection. Upon examination, stool analysis shows cylindrical worms as given below. Which of the following features is most characteristic of the female worm?

options.label: A
options.text: Ventral curvature of the posterior end

options.label: D
options.text: Smaller size compared to the male

questions.correct_answer: C. A straight conical posterior end
questions.explanation:
Roundworm (Ascaris lumbricoides)

Habitat

Adult worms reside in the small intestine (85% in the jejunum and 15% in the ileum) and are the largest nematode parasites in humans.

Morphology

  

Adult Worms: Large, cylindrical, with tapering ends and pale pink color that turns white outside the body.

Male Worms:

  • Smaller than females (15-30 cm long, 2-4 mm thick)
  • A ventrally curved posterior end and two copulatory spicules. (Options A & B)

Female Worms:

  • Larger than males (Option D)
  • Straight, conical posterior end (Option C) & a vulvar groove aiding in mating.

Reproduction

A single female can lay up to 200,000 eggs daily, which are expelled in the feces.

Host

Humans only

Infective Form

Embryonated eggs with L2 larvae.

Transmission

Ingestion of eggs from contaminated soil, food, or water.
